                                     Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed Scholars Program                                               Academics                                                              Academics                                                       Instructors                              Staff                              Course Descriptions                                                                                                          During the US trip, you will meet important, friendly leaders, visit famous places, make new friendships, have lots and lots of fun — and have snowball fights with your fellow scholars and instructors.            Amira Ragab Abouelhamd, Class of 2010-2011                                                                                                                   Course Descriptions    There are two choices for the primary academic class. Scholars may take either (1) a seminar taught by NYU President John Sexton on the relationship between religion and politics as seen through the lens of US Supreme Court decisions; or (2) a seminar taught by noted journalist, author, and foreign policy expert James Traub on American foreign policy. Scholars may indicate their preference, but their final assignment rests with the program's executive director.                                   Scholars are enrolled in one of the following courses:                                   Expand all [+] Collapse all [-]                                      The U.S. Supreme Court's Treatment of the Relationship Between Church and State            Instructor: John Sexton, President of NYU   Assistant Instructors: Angela Migally & Katy Bartelma      This course is taught by John Sexton, President of NYU and former Dean of NYU's Law School. It will focus on a topic on which he has been a major academic voice: the relationship of government and religion, with a particular emphasis on the way the United States, acting principally through its Supreme Court, has addressed this issue. President Sexton has taught this course for twenty years to undergraduates at NYU; it is designed to familiarize students with the workings of the American Constitutional system (especially the role of the courts), and to teach the skills of critical analysis, close reading of text, and persuasive writing. Because the course moves beyond the substance of the material to the broader intellectual skills involved, it appeals to students in a wide range of disciplines. Students must be prepared to invest a great deal of time preparing for class; a written paper of five to six pages is required for most classes, and the readings for each class are extensive. Additionally, students must be willing to participate in the classroom debate and be subject to rigorous questioning by the professor. President Sexton's teaching team includes two American-trained attorneys who will work with scholars in developing the important skills of critical thinking and persuasive writing.                                 US Foreign Policy            Instructor: James Traub, Journalist & Author   Assistant Instructor: Peter Vining    This course will examine the themes, influences, and controversies in the development and execution of US foreign policy over the past 100 years. Moving chronologically, we will cover six key periods in which the United States has had to define and redefine its role in the world:   World War I, Woodrow Wilson, and the League of Nations   War, Cold War, and The New International Order   Cold War and Vietnam   Détente, Human Rights, and "The Evil Empire"   George Bush and the Post-9/11 World   The Age of Obama   Reading the words of leaders and scholars, as well as examining the events of the time, we will learn how successive generations have found very different solutions to the tension between the "national interest" and idealism, and between "unilateralism" and working with international institutions. We will weigh the success and failure of these policies, as a prelude to understanding and assessing the foreign policy of President Obama, which is subject to many of the same forces which have shaped earlier policy, but in a very different world.                                                      Scholars will also participate in the following:                                   Expand all [+] Collapse all [-]                                      What Makes a Great Leader?            Instructor : Diane C. Yu, Executive Director of SMSP & Deputy President of NYU   Assistant Instructors: Melissa Friesen & Molly Higbie   This leadership development program explores some of the ways in which leaders, particularly over the past two centuries, have arisen in a number of settings. How do we define greatness in leadership? Have the standards remained static, or have they changed over time? How have leaders overcome the obstacles in their paths? What traits, if any, do they have in common? Do leaders make the times in which they serve, or do the times dictate the leaders who emerge? Are leadership skills innate, or can they be learned and developed?   The seminar will stimulate thinking through readings and discussion about leadership theories, research, and trends, as well as notable figures from the past and present in a variety of settings. Readings include selections from biography, analysis and commentary, history, and autobiography. The seminar also features private sessions with prominent leadership figures from the UAE and the United States who will discuss their views, experiences, and firsthand observations about leadership. Over the past three years, the Scholars have met with notable leaders in the UAE such as:     His Highness Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed Al Nahyan   The Right Honorable Gordon Brown, MP, Former Prime Minister of the United Kingdom and Distinguished Global Leader in Residence, NYU   US Ambassador to the UAE, Richard Olson   CNBC Arabiya CEO, Stephen F. Hall   Chief Justice of the UAE Supreme Court, Dr. Abdul Wahab Abdul   UAE Presidential Advisor, H.E. Zaki Nusseibeh   First Vice President of the Federal National Council, H.E. Ahmed Bin Shabib Al Dhaheri     During the past three US trips, Scholars have met with individuals such as:     Former US Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Connor   US Senator Lamar Alexander   US House of Representatives member Diana DeGette   Assistant Secretary of State Philip Goldberg   Middle East Advisor to Vice President Biden, Herro Mustafa   Actress and playwright Anna Deavere Smith   UN Development Programme head, Stephane Dujarrac   UAE Ambassador to the US, Yousef Al Otaiba                                   Public Speaking & Public Presentations            Instructor: Diane C. Yu, Executive Director of SMSP & Deputy President of NYU   Assistant Instructor: Molly Higbie   This course is designed to help students improve their public speaking skills and learn how to confidently present on variety of topics in diverse settings. The course offers intensive feedback and correction on students' spoken English and includes videotaping of formal and informal presentations to provide students a record of their progress. Final presentations will be assessed by a panel of judges.                                 Critical Thinking and Persuasive Writing            Instructor : Laurie Behringer, Senior Director   Assistant Instructor: Jonathan Marsh     Critical Thinking and Persuasive Writing is a complement to the academic courses in the program. The course takes place primarily online, although there are also four in-person classes. For the class, the scholars:     Write reflections on their experience with writing and in the program   Engage in critical thinking discussions on questions prompted by the content of their academic classes   Edit the papers they write for their other SMSP courses and learn grammar relevant to their errors   Participate in peer reviews of these papers.     In addition, the online course site serves as a hub for the program — the syllabi, the grades for all the classes in the program, and resources are posted on the site. The instruction in this class is collaborative, as it is throughout the program — preceptors assist with the peer review in the onsite classes, the writing instructor and the preceptors respond to the critical thinking posts, and the writing instructor and preceptors co-teach some of the preceptor sessions that focus on writing issues.                                      Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed Scholars Program                                               Academics                                                              Academics                                                       Instructors                              Staff                              Course Descriptions                                                                                                          During the US trip, you will meet important, friendly leaders, visit famous places, make new friendships, have lots and lots of fun — and have snowball fights with your fellow scholars and instructors.            Amira Ragab Abouelhamd, Class of 2010-2011                                                                                                                   Course Descriptions    There are two choices for the primary academic class. Scholars may take either (1) a seminar taught by NYU President John Sexton on the relationship between religion and politics as seen through the lens of US Supreme Court decisions; or (2) a seminar taught by noted journalist, author, and foreign policy expert James Traub on American foreign policy. Scholars may indicate their preference, but their final assignment rests with the program's executive director.                                   Scholars are enrolled in one of the following courses:                                   Expand all [+] Collapse all [-]                                      The U.S. Supreme Court's Treatment of the Relationship Between Church and State            Instructor: John Sexton, President of NYU   Assistant Instructors: Angela Migally & Katy Bartelma      This course is taught by John Sexton, President of NYU and former Dean of NYU's Law School. It will focus on a topic on which he has been a major academic voice: the relationship of government and religion, with a particular emphasis on the way the United States, acting principally through its Supreme Court, has addressed this issue. President Sexton has taught this course for twenty years to undergraduates at NYU; it is designed to familiarize students with the workings of the American Constitutional system (especially the role of the courts), and to teach the skills of critical analysis, close reading of text, and persuasive writing. Because the course moves beyond the substance of the material to the broader intellectual skills involved, it appeals to students in a wide range of disciplines. Students must be prepared to invest a great deal of time preparing for class; a written paper of five to six pages is required for most classes, and the readings for each class are extensive. Additionally, students must be willing to participate in the classroom debate and be subject to rigorous questioning by the professor. President Sexton's teaching team includes two American-trained attorneys who will work with scholars in developing the important skills of critical thinking and persuasive writing.                                 US Foreign Policy            Instructor: James Traub, Journalist & Author   Assistant Instructor: Peter Vining    This course will examine the themes, influences, and controversies in the development and execution of US foreign policy over the past 100 years. Moving chronologically, we will cover six key periods in which the United States has had to define and redefine its role in the world:   World War I, Woodrow Wilson, and the League of Nations   War, Cold War, and The New International Order   Cold War and Vietnam   Détente, Human Rights, and "The Evil Empire"   George Bush and the Post-9/11 World   The Age of Obama   Reading the words of leaders and scholars, as well as examining the events of the time, we will learn how successive generations have found very different solutions to the tension between the "national interest" and idealism, and between "unilateralism" and working with international institutions. We will weigh the success and failure of these policies, as a prelude to understanding and assessing the foreign policy of President Obama, which is subject to many of the same forces which have shaped earlier policy, but in a very different world.                                                      Scholars will also participate in the following:                                   Expand all [+] Collapse all [-]                                      What Makes a Great Leader?            Instructor : Diane C. Yu, Executive Director of SMSP & Deputy President of NYU   Assistant Instructors: Melissa Friesen & Molly Higbie   This leadership development program explores some of the ways in which leaders, particularly over the past two centuries, have arisen in a number of settings. How do we define greatness in leadership? Have the standards remained static, or have they changed over time? How have leaders overcome the obstacles in their paths? What traits, if any, do they have in common? Do leaders make the times in which they serve, or do the times dictate the leaders who emerge? Are leadership skills innate, or can they be learned and developed?   The seminar will stimulate thinking through readings and discussion about leadership theories, research, and trends, as well as notable figures from the past and present in a variety of settings. Readings include selections from biography, analysis and commentary, history, and autobiography. The seminar also features private sessions with prominent leadership figures from the UAE and the United States who will discuss their views, experiences, and firsthand observations about leadership. Over the past three years, the Scholars have met with notable leaders in the UAE such as:     His Highness Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed Al Nahyan   The Right Honorable Gordon Brown, MP, Former Prime Minister of the United Kingdom and Distinguished Global Leader in Residence, NYU   US Ambassador to the UAE, Richard Olson   CNBC Arabiya CEO, Stephen F. Hall   Chief Justice of the UAE Supreme Court, Dr. Abdul Wahab Abdul   UAE Presidential Advisor, H.E. Zaki Nusseibeh   First Vice President of the Federal National Council, H.E. Ahmed Bin Shabib Al Dhaheri     During the past three US trips, Scholars have met with individuals such as:     Former US Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Connor   US Senator Lamar Alexander   US House of Representatives member Diana DeGette   Assistant Secretary of State Philip Goldberg   Middle East Advisor to Vice President Biden, Herro Mustafa   Actress and playwright Anna Deavere Smith   UN Development Programme head, Stephane Dujarrac   UAE Ambassador to the US, Yousef Al Otaiba                                   Public Speaking & Public Presentations            Instructor: Diane C. Yu, Executive Director of SMSP & Deputy President of NYU   Assistant Instructor: Molly Higbie   This course is designed to help students improve their public speaking skills and learn how to confidently present on variety of topics in diverse settings. The course offers intensive feedback and correction on students' spoken English and includes videotaping of formal and informal presentations to provide students a record of their progress. Final presentations will be assessed by a panel of judges.                                 Critical Thinking and Persuasive Writing            Instructor : Laurie Behringer, Senior Director   Assistant Instructor: Jonathan Marsh     Critical Thinking and Persuasive Writing is a complement to the academic courses in the program. The course takes place primarily online, although there are also four in-person classes. For the class, the scholars:     Write reflections on their experience with writing and in the program   Engage in critical thinking discussions on questions prompted by the content of their academic classes   Edit the papers they write for their other SMSP courses and learn grammar relevant to their errors   Participate in peer reviews of these papers.     In addition, the online course site serves as a hub for the program — the syllabi, the grades for all the classes in the program, and resources are posted on the site. The instruction in this class is collaborative, as it is throughout the program — preceptors assist with the peer review in the onsite classes, the writing instructor and the preceptors respond to the critical thinking posts, and the writing instructor and preceptors co-teach some of the preceptor sessions that focus on writing issues. John | NYU Shanghai                                            Jump to navigation                                      Search form      Search                         中文               Research   Campus Life   Academic Life   Admissions   About                                              All Ranks          Professor          Associate Professor          Assistant Professor          Fellows / Instructors / Lecturers                          You are here Home > Academic Life > Our Faculty > John Sexton            John Sexton                                                                                                     John Sexton                                                   President of New York University and Professor of Law                                                           John Sexton, the fifteenth President of New York University, also is the Benjamin Butler Professor of Law and NYU Law School's Dean Emeritus, having served as Dean for 14 years. He joined the Law School's faculty in 1981, was named the School's Dean in 1988, and was designated the University's President in 2001. He teaches The Relationship Between Government and Religion at NYU Shanghai. President Sexton is a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, a member of the Council on Foreign Relations, and a past member of the Executive Committee of the Association of American Universities. He is past Chair of the American Council on Education, the New York Academy of Sciences, and the Commission on Independent Colleges and Universities of New York. He has served as the Chairman of the Board of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York (2003-2006) and Chair of the Federal Reserve Systems Council of Chairs (2006). He served as a Board Member for the National Association of Securities Dealers (1996-1998), and was Founding Chair of the Board of NASD Dispute Resolution (2000-2002). He also serves on the Board of the Institute of International Education. While Dean of New York University Law School, he was President of the Association of American Law Schools. He is an author of the nation’s leading casebook on Civil Procedure . He also is the author of Redefining the Supreme Court's Role: A Theory of Managing the Federal Court System  (a treatment of the Supreme Court's case selection process) in addition to several other books, numerous chapters, articles and Supreme Court briefs.
